div.p: AUTHORSUMMARY is placed at the opening of WRITING entries. As the equivalent of a Div1, it occurs outside any Div1, standing on its own. It is devised for researchers to make summary statements about an author before opening individual PRODUCTION, RECEPTION, or TEXTUALFEATURES elements. You are encouraged to use this element to preface the writing document of each woman writer. It is useful both for minor writers about whom little is known, and for major writers whose work needs to be summarized before launching into the details. It must be as brief as possible, while situating its subject as to period, most characteristic genres, and reasons for interest in her. It allows use of three main sub-elements: EXTENTOFOEUVRE, GENRENAME, and GENERICRANGE. If you need to say more, then move into a PRODUCTION, RECEPTION, or TEXTUALFEATURES element. The usual Div1 inclusions are also available within AUTHORSUMMARY: NAME, DATE, PLACE, and ORGNAME.

div.codeblock: Anne Clifford's known writings fall into two groups: the diaries she kept as a young woman, and the writings of her old age, which mix diary, autobiography, and writing about her family.
Elizabeth Cellier's output amounts to three pamphlets on topical religious and gender issues.

div.p: Although this element can in principle be used anywhere, the beginning of the document is its normal place. You should limit its length to roughly 160 words where possible. Be sure to tag all instances of GENRENAMES appearing in the AUTHORSUMMARY in addition to tagging the GENERICRANGE (where possible). Note that this paragraph is part of the WRITING schema, not LIFE. It displays, however, on the Overview screen not the WRITING screen; some repetition is therefore permissible.
